In parallel with the efforts on 2D group-VA materials, various tunable approaches have been employed to enrich their properties and expand their applications. These modification methods involve doping, defect, external field (strain and electricity), chemical functionalization, and heterostructure.[56–61] Especially, the internal combination of group-VA elements (AB), which can be viewed as doping A into semiconductor B (named as 2D V-V binary materials), has provided a new perspective to realize tunable atomic structures and electronic properties. Compared with other modu-
lation methods, the approach is very common and manageable in experiments and can diametrically tune the intrinsic properties. Numerous theoretical and experimental research efforts have been made to investigate the band structure, carrier mobility, Rashba effect, topological state in 2D V-V binary materials. Through the interaction among different degrees of freedom (charge, lattice, orbital, spin, etc.), these electronic properties in 2D V-V binary materials can be further modulated. For instance, 2D As-P binary material (black AsP monolayer) has been predicted as a promising alternative material for solar cell due to its favorable direct bandgap, exceeding 14 000 cm2 V−1 s−1 mobility, and high power conversion efficiency (PCE).[62] Exhilaratingly, experimental researches have proved that 2D black AsP is also a potential candidate for application in mid-infrared (MIR) optoelectronics.[63–65] In addition, other 2D V-V binary materials, such as SbP, SbAs, BiSb, have been predicted to possess a considerable bandgap and a high carrier mobility, which are necessary properties for next-generation electronic devices.[66]
Even though many researches have reported the structures, properties, and applications of 2D V-V binary materials, a comprehensive review of this area has yet to be conducted. In this work, we summarize recent advances of 2D V-V binary materials in their properties, syntheses, and applications. We begin with the findings on the theoretical design of 2D V-V binary materials, including their configurations, electronic properties, and different tuning approaches. Then, methodologies for the preparation of their nanosheets are discussed in detail. In addition, we highlight their favorable and potential applications, involving electronics, optoelectronics, and energy devices. At last, we provide a perspective on 2D V-V binary materials. It is expected that this review will offer a comprehensive summary for readers and stimulate further efforts in developing 2D V-V binary materials.
2D phosphorene, arsenene, antimonene, and bismuthene, as a fast-growing family of 2D monoelemental materials, have attracted enormous interest in the scientific community owing to their intriguing structures and extraordinary electronic properties. Tuning the monoelemental crystals into bielemental ones between group-VA elements is able to preserve their advantages of unique structures, modulate their properties, and further expand their multifunctional applications. Herein, a review of the historical work is provided for both theoretical predictions and experimental advances of 2D V-V binary materials. Their various intriguing electronic properties are discussed, including band structure, carrier mobility, Rashba effect, and topological state.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The scientific breakthrough in graphene research has sparked immense interests in 2D materials, ranging from hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), transition metal chalcogenides to a class of monoelemental 2D materials (Si, Ge, Sn, etc.).[1–5] Among the emerging 2D materials, black phosphorene is a significant monoelemental 2D material owing to its robust direct bandgap, high hole mobility, unique anisotropic characteristic, and holedominated ambipolar transport behavior.[6–11] Subsequently, the cousins of black phosphorene, which are arsenene,[12–14] antimonene,[15–20] and bismuthene,[21–26] have been successfully fabricated and become the important new members of 2D family.[27–32] These 2D group-VA materials possess different allotropes with fascinating properties, thus making them suitable for a broad range of applications, including

sections.heading: 2. Theoretical Design of 2D V-V Binary Materials
sections.text: Group-VA elements consist of nitrogen (N, Z = 7), phosphorus (P, Z = 15), arsenic (As, Z = 33), antimony (Sb, Z = 51), bismuth (Bi, Z = 83), and extremely radioactive moscovium (Mc, Z = 115). Considering the extremely radioactive nature of Mc, the combination of group-VA elements is discussed between two of the first five elements. Notably, except that nitrogen exists as a gas at room temperature, the other four elements (P, As, Sb, and Bi) have been successfully fabricated into 2D layered materials, commonly known as phosphorene, arsenene, antimonene, and bismuthene, respectively. If two of these elements are combined into a binary material, no matter what percentage of the two components is, we generally name them as “2D V-V binary materials.” In this section, the intrinsic motivation of the combination is discussed. Then, we describe the fundamental properties of these 2D V-V binary materials, including structural and electronic properties. Finally, different approaches to modify their electronic properties through coupling of degrees of freedom (charge, lattice, orbital, and spin) are also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.2. Stability of 2D V-V Binary Materials
sections.text:
Before discussing the stability of 2D V-V binary materials, it is necessary to mention that among diverse 2D group-VA allotropes (Figure 2a), the stable ones are α and β phases. Their
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1902352

relative stability was discussed by calculating the cohesive energy.[15] As shown in Figure 2a, α-phosphorene (also called as black phosphorene) has the lowest energy, while for arsenene, antimonene, and bismuthene, β phase is the most stable. The relative stability of α and β phases for 2D V-V binary materials is also identified by comparing their cohesive energies, which are summarized in Table 1. Essentially, some theoretical reports have verified that the cohesive energy of 2D V-V binary materials is comparable with that of the corresponding group-VA monoelemental materials. Zhu et al. explored that the cohesive energy of 2D AsxP1−x rises with increasing proportion of phosphorus, but always between that of 2D P and As, as shown in Figure 2b.[71] Also, similar result has been found in 2D AsSb.[72]
Besides cohesive energy, theoretical researchers further performed phonon dispersion calculations (Figure 2c) and ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations (Figure 2d) to examine their dynamical and thermodynamic stability. As shown in Figure 2c, no imaginary frequency is observed in the phonon spectra, indicating that their atomic structures are dynamically stable.[73–77] Furthermore, AIMD simulations also show their high stability that atomic structures do not spontaneously reshape during the simulations at room temperature and even up to 1000 K.[74–82] In addition, using first-principles cluster-expansion method in combination with canonical Monte Carlo simulation further confirms the good phase stability of SbAs monolayer under various temperatures.[83] The above theoretical reports indicate that 2D V-V binary materials can exist as freestanding 2D crystals at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electronic Properties of 2D V-V Binary Materials
sections.text:
Many theoretical studies have examined the fundamental electronic properties of 2D V-V binary materials, to reflect their feasibility in electronic and photoelectronic applications.[84,85] The bandgaps of 2D V-V binary materials at Perdew–Burke– Ernzerhof (PBE) functional and Heyd–Scuseria–Ernzerhof (HSE) hybrid functional are summarized in Table 2. It is generally known that PBE method often underestimates the bandgap.[86] Hence, we also give the more reliable bandgap values at HSE functional, which can overcome this underestimated problem.[87] Owing to the interplay among orbital, charge, and lattice, 2D V-V binary materials show favorable
electronic properties different from 2D group-VA materials. The bandgaps of 2D V-V binary materials cover a wider range than those of 2D group-VA materials. Furthermore, for 2D V-V binary materials, nine of them present direct bandgap, as shown in Figure 3. However, there are only three direct-bandgap semiconductors among 2D group-VA materials, which are α-phosphorene, α-bismuthene, and β-bismuthene.
Spin-orbit coupling (SOC) effect, related to the relativistic effects, increases approximately with the growth of Z4, where Z is the atomic number. The strong SOC effect of heavy elements dramatically affects the electronic structures of 2D materials. Zhang and Chen[88] calculated the band structures of β-AsP, β-SbP, β-BiP, β-SbAs, β-BiAs, and β-BiSb based on HSE06

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Composition
sections.text:
2D V-V binary materials with different compositions can be dominated by controlling the proportion of two precursors in experiment, as shown in Figure 4a. If combining two different elements, their different atom radii induce strain to change the lattice, and their different electronegativities result in charge transfer and orbital recombination, leading to the modification of structural and electronic properties. It has been predicted that for 2D V-V binary materials, changing percent composition results in effective modification of electronic properties, sometimes accompanied by phase transition between α and β phases (Figure 4b).[71,72] Zhu et al. found that AsxP1−x monolayer transfers from α to β phase when x is larger than 0.07, which is similar with AsxP1−x bulk.[71,100] For α-AsxP1−x monolayer, the indirect–direct-bandgap transition occurs when x is equal to 0.25. While for β-AsxP1−x monolayer, although no indirect– direct-bandgap transition is observed, the characteristic of the frontier states changes. Particularly, the frontier states of valence band shift more obviously than those of conduction band in virtue of these compounds behaving as p-type semiconductors. The anisotropic structure and tunable bandgap of 2D α-AsxP1−x with respect to the percent composition bring about its tunable anisotropic optical absorption property covering visible and ultraviolet regions.[78] Interestingly, the atomic arrangement of 2D β-V-V materials can also induce obvious anisotropic characteristic in transport properties.
The transport properties, which are significantly dependent on the electronic structures, can also be tuned by changing component percentage. For 2D α-Sb1−xAsx, the ones with direct bandgap have lighter effective mass than pristine 2D As and Sb, and even lighter than black phosphorene.[72] As a result, the carrier mobility of α-Sb1−xPx monolayer is tuned to 2 × 104 cm2 V−1 s−1, twice more than the mobility of black phosphorene.[90] Apart from changing the component percentage, atomic arrangement also effectively modulates the electronic properties.[101] Moreover, the low transport current of 2D AsP is enhanced by appropriate component percentage and atomic positional fluctuation.[102]

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Defect and Doping
sections.text:
It is difficult to avoid defects during the growth and preparation process, especially in 2D materials. Although defects are generally considered to be detrimental to device performance, they can create new favorable effects in the electronic, magnetic, and chemical properties through coupling of charge and spin. Structure defects of 2D materials can be divided into point defects, line defects, and planar defects. Typical point defects include
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1902352
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1902352 (6 of 19)
single vacancies, double vacancies, Stone–Wales defects, and adatoms, as shown in Figure 4c. Several theoretical reports confirmed that defects inevitably influence the electronic and magnetic properties of 2D group-VA materials, which is also observed in 2D V-V binary materials.[103–107] In 2D α-AsP, P or As vacancy not only decreases the spin-up bandgap but also invites an ≈1 µB magnetization, which is mainly derived from the neighbor atoms around the vacancy.[106,107] While for β phase, the absence of P or As atom promotes the system to display a metallic character.[106,107] 2D β-SbAs with adatom defects exhibits 1.0 µB magnetism per supercell, due to the unpaired electrons of group-VA atoms.[105] Besides the adatom defects, an As or Sb single vacancy defect (SVAs or SVsb) also brings a 1.0 µB per supercell magnetic moment in β-AsSb monolayer. By calculating the projected density of states, it is shown that the magnetism in SVAs originates in the p orbitals of three surrounding Sb atoms, but the magnetism in SVSb is mainly derived from the p orbitals of only one surrounding As atom. Moreover, the SVAs structure shows metallic property. However, the SVSb still preserves a semiconductor property, as well as the SV in β-Sb. The other defects, including Stone–Wales defects and double vacancy (5-8-5), obviously reduce its bandgap. Apart from structural defects, hole doping can also induce magnetism in 2D V-V binary materials. Nie et al. studied the influence of generally increasing hole doping on electronic and magnetic properties of β-V-N monolayers (V = P, As, Sb, Bi).[76] As the hole-doping density increases to 0.03 holes per cell, a ferromagnetic ground state is found in β-SbN monolayer. As the density gradually increases to 0.08 holes per cell, the valence band of β-SbN monolayer crosses over Fermi level, displaying a half-metal character. While under higher hole doping density, the spin splitting of the valence band emerges and reaches the maximum value of 2 eV (at PBE level) at 1 hole per cell. Especially, under 0.6 holes per cell, the spin-splitting gap still has a large value of 1.2 eV at PBE level (corrected to 3.1 eV at HSE level). Considering the carrier doping can be obtained by an external voltage gate experimentally, to study the influence of electric field on the electronic properties is urgent, as an

important step forward toward the application of β-V-N monolayers in spintronics.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Heterostructure
sections.text:
As shown in Figure 4d, there are two typical heterostructures, lateral interfacing atomic monolayers connected by covalent bonds (termed with lateral heterostructures) and vertically stacked multilayers formed by van der Waals forces (termed with vertical heterostructures). It is much more flexible to construct vertical heterostructures than lateral heterostructures because of the reduced requirements for lattice match.[108,109] In addition, lateral heterostructures can only be synthesized by chemical vapor deposition (CVD). However, vertical heterostructures have been prepared by direct CVD growth, epitaxial methods, or mechanically stacking a series of 2D materials, showing greater advantages in practical applications.[110–114] The vertical heterostructures are also known as van der Waals heterostructures (vdWHs). On account of the coupling of individual layers, vdWHs are expected to simultaneously possess the advantages of the individual ones, or generate novel physical properties. Therefore, the building of vdWHs further provides opportunities to overcome the limitations of individual components and to fabricate ideal electronic and optoelectronic devices.
Given that 2D V-V binary materials and 2D group-VA materials share very similar geometrical parameters, it is natural to create vdWHs between them. Yu et al. constructed SbN and phosphorene vdWHs (SbN/P) in both α and β phases.[74] The α- (SbN/P) vdWH shows a 0.91 eV direct bandgap close to black phosphorene. Notably, β-(SbN/P) vdWH turns into a direct-bandgap semiconductor although both β-SbN and β-P monolayers present an indirect gap. 2D group-IV materials also possess a 2D buckled hexagonal lattice, similar to the structure of 2D β-V-V materials. Fortunately, the lattice parameters of β-SbAs monolayer and silicene are very closed, predicted to be about 3.86 Å, resulting in a negligible lattice mismatch.[115] Firstprinciples calculations indicated that β-SbAs monolayer opens a bandgap for silicene in the vdWH, and simultaneously preserve its nearly linear band dispersion with high carrier mobility. Moreover, the indirect bandgap of the vdWH is effectively modified to direct bandgap by adjusting the interlayer distance.

sections.heading: 2.4.4. Strain
sections.text:
External fields, including strain engineering and electric fields (Figure 4e), have been affirmed to be an efficient and economical approach to tune the electronic properties of nanomaterials.[116] Ultrathin 2D materials usually have ultrahigh mechanical flexibility, which is possible to suffer considerable strain without structural destruction. The combination between degrees of freedom (lattice and orbital) induced by strain engineering brings about novel properties. Theoretical calculations have indicated that the electronic properties of 2D V-V binary materials are sensitive to in-plane strain and the breaking strain is even larger than 20%. Their nonplanar structures allow a high external strain without a large energy cost, similar to 2D group-VA materials.[117,118] 2D V-V binary materials with an
indirect bandgap, such as α-PN, α-AsN, α-AsP, and β-SbAs, are modulated to be a direct-bandgap semiconductor if applying appropriate strain.[74,119–122] Meanwhile, the sizable bandgap is efficiently tuned by increasing compression or tensile strain and finally turns into 0 eV while reaching a certain strain. Especially, for 2D α-V-V materials, the sensitivity of band structures to strain along different in-plane directions exists obvious difference due to their structural anisotropy.[97,121,122] For instance, the band structure of α-PN monolayer is more sensitive to the tensile strain along zigzag direction than armchair direction. Its bandgap closes up when the tensile strain reaches 8% along the zigzag direction. But along the armchair direction, the tensile strain has to arrive at 18%.[122]
Through tuning the electronic properties, strain engineering can further extend the applications of 2D V-V binary materials. 2D V-V binary materials, especially comprising of heavy elements with robust SOC effect, will experience semiconductor-TI (topological insulator) transitions with increasing compression or tensile strain. 2D β phases of AsP, SbP, BiP, SbAs, BiAs, BiSb have been reported to have straininduced topological phase transition under lattice strain.[77] The topological phase transition can be revealed by the evolution of bonding and antibonding states in band structure. Zhang et al. found that the band inversion of β-SbAs monolayer occurs once the biaxial strain is larger than 12%.[89] Its Z2 topological invariant also transforms from 0 to 1, further confirming the topological phase transition. The topological phase transition emerges in 2D β-BiSb if biaxial tensile strain increases to 14%.[123] Intriguingly, in-plane biaxial strain strengthens the Rashba spin splitting of β-BiSb monolayer.[82] These 2D V-V binary materials with attractive electronic properties are highly promising for potential applications in alternative electronics and spintronics. In energy conversion field, strain engineering can enhance the water-splitting performance of β-PN monolayer through tuning the electronic and adsorption properties.[124] Under the 10% tensile strain, β-PN monolayer shows very narrow bandgap and strong adsorption of near-ultraviolet light, which is more suitable in photocatalytic water splitting.

sections.heading: 2.4.5. Substrate
sections.text:
The substrate effect plays an important role in 2D group-VA materials and 2D V-V binary materials. The epitaxial substrate can not only stabilize the 2D materials but also effectively modulate their electronic properties. The modulation is realized by the introducing strain due to the lattice mismatch between 2D materials and substrates.[125]
Some experimental studies have reported the successful growth of antimonene monolayer on different substrates such as PdTe2, Ge, and Ag.[126–128] The three substrates have different lattice mismatches with antimonene that determine its lattice constant and buckling height. PdTe2 and Ge(111) have a very small lattice mismatch with that of freestanding antimonene.[126,127] Hence, the fabricated antimonene monolayers on them show a buckled honeycomb lattice with similar lattice constants (4.13 Å for PdTe2 and 4.27 Å for Ge), like its freestanding conformation. Different from PdTe2 and Ge(111), Ag(111) substrate has a large lattice mismatch with antimonene, facilitating the formation of
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1902352
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1902352 (8 of 19)
flat antimonene monolayer.[128] Scanning tunneling microscopy measurements demonstrate that the antimonene on Ag(111) substrate shows a large lattice constant of 5.01 Å and a low height of 2.2 Å, confirming its flat atomic structure. Furthermore, the flat honeycomb structure shows a semi-metal feature with a gapped Dirac cone below the Fermi level. The unique property is derived from its flat structure, where in-plane sp2 orbital and out-of-plane pz orbital is decoupled. Also, the induced topological property in flat antimonene has been realized in flat bismuthene grown on SiC.[22] Under the strain effect of SiC substrate, the lattice parameter of grown bismuthene monolayer is 5.35 Å, which is larger than that of freestanding bismuthene. In addition to providing a strain to stabilize the planar bismuthene, the SiC substrate makes contribution to obtain a large bulk gap of approximately 0.8 eV, thereby realizing the high-temperature quantum spin Hall material.
However, a large lattice mismatch sometimes does not induce a strain on 2D materials. For instance, 2D BiSb can be grown on GaAs(111) or MnGa substrate without strain effect despite the large lattice mismatch between them.[66,129,130] Nevertheless, the substrate still contributes a lot in the system. For instance, the model ferromagnet MnGa can provide a perfect perpendicular magnetization and achieve ultralow power magnetization switching together with 2D BiSb.[66]

sections.heading: 3. Realizing 2D V-V Binary Materials
sections.text: In order to study their superior properties and high-performance applications, it is necessary to realize the production of 2D V-V nanosheets with high quality and large-area uniformity. Due to their layered structures, 2D V-V binary materials can be prepared via typical synthetic methods of 2D crystals. 2D nanosheets can be achieved through top-down approaches (mechanical exfoliation, liquid exfoliation, electrochemical exfoliation, etc.) and bottom-up approaches (CVD, wet chemical synthesis, molecular beam epitaxy (MBE), etc.). Bottom-up approaches cater to two distinct purposes: 1) directly growing an independent 2D nanosheet, and 2) growing layered bulk crystals that are suitable to be exfoliated into 2D nanosheets. 2D V-V binary materials have been successfully prepared utilizing individual bottom-up approaches or mechanical exfoliation method after bottom-up approaches.

sections.heading: 3.1. Vapor Transport Method (VTM)
sections.text:
VTM is a significant approach to synthesize 2D V-V binary materials. The VTM is regarded as one form of CVD, which has been widely applied to grow 2D materials since it can easily control quality and morphology of materials. Although VTMsynthesized 2D V-V binary materials are rarely found in the literatures, some reports have described the synthesis of bulk crystal through VTM and obtained single- or few-layer V-V binary materials followed by exfoliation.
The VTM has been employed to synthesize α-AsP, β-BiSb, and violet SbP bulk crystals with different nominal compositions. The precursors used to prepare α-AsP are generally red phosphorus and gray arsenic.[100,131] To change the molar ratio
of the two precursors is able to manage the As-P composition percentage of synthetic samples. For instance, by this method, Zhou et al. prepared α-P (α-As0P1), α-As0.25P0.75, and α-As0.4P0.6 samples.[131] Furthermore, presynthesized lead iodide (PbI2) or tin/tin (IV) iodide (Sn/SnI) was utilized as the starting material and added as mineralization agent to facilitate the phase formation and crystal growth. The mixture was heated above melting point, generating vapor that further reacted into binary compound. Then, few-layer α-AsP flakes were obtained from bulk samples via mechanical exfoliation. Like black phosphorene, the isolated α-AsP nanosheets suffer from degrading upon exposure to ambient conditions. The encapsulation of exfoliated α-AsP flake by poly-methyl methacrylate can avoid its degradation over a period of several months. Violet SbP is also a layered material, like the structure of violet phosphorus. Zhou et al. reported the preparation of violet SbP by blending antimony, red phosphorus, and lead mixture.[132] The mixture was first heated to 770 K for 10 h, and then kept at this temperature for 48 h, finally cooled to room temperature. To prepare V-V crystals including P, one of the precursors is red phosphorus. If one of the two ingredients is As, Sb, or Bi, the corresponding precursor is their most stable bulk martial (β phase). Nevertheless, it is very difficult to grow nitrides using the VTM due to the absence of nitrogen solid at room temperature.
In V-V binary materials such as α-AsxP1−x, existence of several different chemical bonds results in different vibration modes from group-VA monoelemental materials, which can be observed in Raman spectra. Black α-AsxP1−x bulk crystals were reported with highly tunable chemical compositions.[131] Figure 5a depicts AsP flakes with orthorhombic structure, which is similar to the puckered structure of black phosphorene. As arsenic percentage increases, the P-P peaks in X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern are generally weakened, and new P-As peaks arise in the middle frequency region. The PP, AsAs, and AsP bonds in α-AsP exhibit different Raman peaks from the corresponding bonds in pure phosphorene or arsenene (Figure 5b). The obvious changes of Raman peaks are supported by theoretical predictions based on density functional theory calculations. The atomic force microscope (AFM) image in Figure 5c shows a 1.3 nm thickness α-As0.83P0.17 flake, corresponding to two atomic layers on account of the measured 0.51 nm layer thickness (Figure 5d). Furthermore, the bandgap of α-AsxP1−x can be tuned with the composition changes, which will be discussed in Section 4.2.
Unlike other layered materials, the exfoliated violet SbP nanosheets show rectangular configuration with regular sharp edges (Figure 5e).[132] The regular sharps usually exist in materials directly grown by bottom-up techniques, but rarely observed in exfoliated 2D layered materials.[133,134] The violet SbP with high surface quality is a promising material in the field-effect transistors (FETs).

sections.heading: 3.2. MBE
sections.text:
MBE is another significant bottom-up approach, which has been widely applied to grow 2D materials.[135,136] It is a facile method to obtain high-quality and uniform materials in ultrahigh vacuum and relatively low temperature compared
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1902352
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1902352 (9 of 19)
to CVD method. Various 2D materials, such as graphene,[137] GaSe,[138] HfSe2/MoSe2,[139] and MoTe2/MoS2,[140] have been synthesized by MBE method. Specifically, 2D group-VA materials, such as β-phosphorene,[141–143] α-antimonene,[144] β-anti monene,[126,127] and β-bismuthene,[23,145,146] have been reported to be successfully grown by MBE method. Through reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED) monitoring, the thickness of layers can be controlled precisely, making MBE a promising method for synthesizing 2D materials.
α-AsP nanosheets have been synthesized on InP substrates in an MBE system.[147] Although MBE technique is applied, the synthesis of α-AsP nanosheets follows an atomic-layer deposition growth mechanism due to the large lattice mismatch between AsP and substrates. The synthetic route is shown in Figure 6a. InP substrates were preheated to 510 °C to remove moisture and pollutants on the surface. Subsequently, the substrate temperature was cooled down to −34 °C for deposition, to prevent re-evaporation of phosphorus from InP surface because of its high vapor pressure. The P2 and As2 source fluxes were recorded to be 7.1 × 10−7 and 1.7 × 10−8 Torr, respectively. The deposited α-AsP nanosheets were then passivated with Al2O3 to prevent the degradation under ambient conditions. Except as the protective layer of α-AsP, the Al2O3 encapsulation causes stress inside the nanosheet during the following thermal annealing process, resulting in its phase transformation. The optimal annealing temperature is 250–350 °C and the residence time is 3–10 days, as qualified by Raman results. Excessive temperatures would cause the degradation and mechanical fracture of both substrate and passivation. If annealing for shorter time, no obvious phase transformation occurs. The composition of α-AsP nanosheets was evaluated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and electron dispersive spectroscopy measurements. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) image in Figure 6b and d-spacing analysis were performed to identify the structure of
AsP samples. The TEM profile image (Figure 6c) shows that AsP nanosheet thickness is about 6 nm, protected by 17 nm Al2O3.
In 2017, Hai et al. reported the MBE growth of high-quality β-BiSb nanosheets on GaAs(111) substrates.[129,130] Through optimizing the growth conditions, the Sb concentration can be modified from 0 to 1. At 570 °C, GaAs buffer layer was grown on the GaAs(111) substrates to acquire atomically smooth surface for following MBE growth of β-BiSb thin films. Subsequently, the MBE growth of β-BiSb thin films was conducted at low temperature (100–250 °C), which was dependent on the Sb concentration. The precise Sb concentrations of β-BiSb samples were measured by the inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry method. Their precise thicknesses were measured by X-ray reflectivity and their crystallographic orientation was measured by XRD. Furthermore, they performed in situ RHEED patterns to observe the MBE growing process of β-BiSb with different Sb concentration. Notably, in order to obtain higher Sb concentration, a higher growth temperature was required for epitaxial growth. Simultaneously, longer growth time was taken to get a streaky RHEED pattern. Hai et al. further realized the high-quality MBE growth of β-BiSb thin films on MnGa, to form a Bi0.9Sb0.1/MnGa bilayer as the spin Hall TI for ultralow power spin-orbit torque (SOT) switching.[66]
In summary, these merits make MBE an effective method for synthesizing large area 2D group V-V binary materials and high-yield vdWHs.[138]

sections.heading: 3.3. Melt Growth
sections.text:
Melt growth is the most common and important method for growing bulk single crystals of inorganic materials, experiencing liquid–solid transitions during the growth process.[148] Most inorganic crystals covering semiconductors,
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1902352
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1902352 (10 of 19)
oxides, halide crystals, metals, and other materials are obtained using this technique in many fields. There are several important melt growth methods, including crystal pulling, Bridgman method, Kyropoulos method, zone melting, flame fusion, and heat exchanger method. The melt growth process consists of three steps: 1) melting above its melt point, 2) solidifying on a seed crystal, 3) growing under a temperature gradient.
By melt growth method, cleavable layered materials such as GeP and SiAs bulk crystals have been successfully synthesized in 2016.[149] In the case of V-V binary materials, SbAs single crystals with 1 mm per side have been prepared in 2013.[150] Single crystals of bulk Bi1−xSbx have also been grown by Bridgeman method and zone melting method with tunable concentration of Sb,[151–154] where the materials are either completely or partially molten in the crucible. Although there is no report on melt growing 2D V-V binary materials, the synthesis of BiSb with nanostructures suggests their possibility and gives some hints. The preparation procedure and characterization of nanoporous Bi2Sb6 are shown in Figure 7a,b.[155] They used a kind of alloying and dealloying method to produce nanoporous BixSb1−x. First, pure Mg, Bi, and Sb precursors were heated to 740 °C in crucible and then casted into the mold. Afterward, the obtained MgBiSb ingot was quickly frozen into a foil using a single-roller melt-spinning apparatus at 1000 r min−1. Finally, they used 2 wt% tartaric acid solution to remove Mg from the foils, rinsed the samples completely using ethanol and water, and dried them at 60 °C for 5 h. The last dealloying process is crucial because the interesting nanoporous BiSb structure with nanoscale ligaments is formed when the active element (Mg) is electively etched away.[156]

sections.heading: 4.1. Electronic Devices
sections.text:
As an essential part of most modern electronic products, FETs are one of the most widely used semiconductor devices, as shown in Figure 8a. An excellent candidate semiconductor as the channel material in FETs needs a suitable bandgap for decent on–off current ratios and fast switching, a high mobility for large on-state current densities. Compared with classical 3D electronic materials, 2D layered semiconductors have superior characteristics, such as pristine surfaces without dangling bonds, sizable bandgaps (1–2 eV), and no coupling with phonons. The subnanometer thickness of 2D crystals confines carriers moving in only two dimensions, resulting in the carriers to be easily controlled by gate voltage for excellent gate electrostatics. Furthermore, to satisfy the current requirement of shrinking the device size, 2D material is a favorable substitute for 3D material to effectively avoid the serious short-channel effect of 3D material in FETs.
The transport properties of 2D materials are summarized in Table 3. FET made from graphene has a high mobility (≈104 cm2 V−1 s−1)[157] but low on–off current ratio (<10),[158] whereas MoS2 has a high on–off current ratio up to 108 but low mobility (only ≈200 cm2 V−1 s−1),[159] severely limiting their device performance. Surprisingly, many experimental studies have demonstrated that black phosphorene FET has the superiorities of both high on–off current ratio (≈105) and high mobility (≈103 cm2 V−1 s−1).[34] The features of phosphorene are its ambipolar behavior, electronical anisotropy, high elasticity, and superior flexibility. The mobility of black phosphorene nanoribbon FETs is dependent on its width and thickness.[160]
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1902352
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1902352 (11 of 19)
The maximum of hole mobility reaches up to 862 cm2 V−1 s−1 based on the 28 nm thick device and the on–off current ratio increases to 103 for 4 nm thickness channel at room temperature. As the cousins of phosphorene, arsenene, and antimonene are favorable channel materials in FETs due to their considerable bandgap and carrier mobility.[15,91] Theoretically, the double-gated FETs based on sub-10 nm arsenene or antimonene are predicted to show superior device performances.[161] In early 2019, bismuthene FETs have been successfully fabricated, exhibiting a carrier mobility of 220 cm2 V−1 s−1 but low switching ratio (<10). The low switching ratio can be explained by the semi-metal feature of bismuthene or the screening effect of the gate electric field.[162]
As the derivatives of 2D group-VA materials, 2D V-V materials have been predicted to possess the considerable bandgap, high carrier mobility, and anisotropy of charge transport, rendering them the favorable channel materials in FETs. Surprisingly, 2D α-AsP FETs have been successfully fabricated in experiment and show good transport performance. Zhou et al. fabricated and measured FET based on α-As0.83P0.17 flake with ≈5 nm thickness.[131] The device shows an on–off ratio of 1.9 × 103, a hole mobility of 110 cm2 V−1 s−1, and an interesting ambipolar transport behavior. Subsequently, the mobility of α-AsP-based FETs has been improved to be 596 and ≈307 cm2 V−1 s−1.[63,65] Moreover, the transport properties of AsP was predicted to be further improved through carefully designing their percentage and atomic arrangement.[102]
The realization of TI phase in 2D V-V binary materials provides opportunities for the application in another important electronic device, topological spintronic device. In fact, as early as 2008, 3D TI state has been discovered in bulk BiSb, where the massive Dirac particles were directly observed using angleresolved photoemission spectroscopy.[163] Considering that the edge states of 2D TIs are more robust against back-scattering than the surface states of 3D TIs, reducing the dimensionality of bulk BiSb seems to be a good choice.[164] Single crystal thin films of β-Bi1−xSbx have been successfully grown on silicon, as thin as ≈30 Å for 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.32.[165] The Fermi surface of the films shows nontrivial Z2 topological number. Furthermore, TI surface state is observed upon reducing the thickness of β-BiSb thin films, indicating the significant effect of the surface volume ratio in TI materials.
To realize 2D Z2 TI state, various methods have been proposed to induce band inversion in 2D narrow-gap semiconductors. For V-V binary monolayers, strong SOC effect of heavy elements can effectively narrow their bandgaps. Strain engineering is an efficient approach to drive the band inversion of 2D V-V binary crystals. By considering SOC effect, β-SbAs and β-BiSb monolayers can be tuned to be TIs under biaxial tensile strain larger than 12% and 14%, respectively.[89,123] Moreover, β-AsP, β-SbP, β-BiP, and β-BiAs monolayers also experience semiconductor-TI transition with increasing lattice strain.[77] These ultrathin V-V binary materials are highly favorable for applications in alternative topological spintronic devices.
Besides TIs, 2D V-V binary materials possess other curious physical properties, which expand their potential applications in future spintronics. Theoretically, β-BiSb monolayer has been found to have a giant Rashba spin splitting near the Fermi level.[82] The obtained Rashba spin-splitting parameters are ER = 13 meV, αR = 2.3 eVÅ, which is further enhanced by in-plane biaxial strain. After forming the heterostructure with AlN, its direct bandgap and Rashba spin splitting still exist. The Rashba splitting of the Bi-terminated heterostructure is stronger than that of the Sb-terminated heterostructure because of the stronger SOC effect of Bi. Another V-V binary material, SbAs monolayer, after functionalized with H and halogen atoms, possesses both spin and valley polarized Dirac states (called SbAsX2, as shown in Figure 8b).[166] Its strong SOC effect results in a giant spin splitting with inversion symmetry breaking. Especially, the bandgap of SbAsH2 closes only if applied 2.3% critical strain, which is easily obtained in experiment. These outstanding properties pave the way to use 2D V-V binary materials as candidates of highly efficient spin FETs and optoelectronics devices.
To realize SOT, TIs with spin Hall effect should possess both a high conductivity and large spin Hall angle. BiSb nanosheets have been examined to possess a high conductivity exceeding 105 Ω−1 m−1.[129] Therefore, combined with its strong SOC effect and high carrier mobility, BiSb is suitable for SOT switching in magnetoresistive random-access memory (MRAM). In 2018, high-quality BiSb thin films grown on MnGa have been confirmed as candidate materials for SOT-MRAM, as shown in Figure 8c–f.[66] At room temperature, BiSb/MnGa bilayer holds a large spin Hall angle of 52, which is the highest value reported so far. An ultralow current density is observed in BiSb/MnGa

sections.heading: 4.2. Optoelectronics
sections.text:
Photodetector is another important application for semiconductor. In comparison with 3D materials employed in photodetectors, 2D materials exhibit many exceptional properties, such as a robust polarization dependence, strong light–matter
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1902352
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1902352 (13 of 19)
interactions, and high photoresponse.[173–175] Black phosphorene possesses high carrier mobility, as well as thicknessdependent bandgap covering the visible to MIR spectral range. In addition, its optical properties have been widely studied and the photodetectors show remarkably high performances, indicating that phosphorene is a promising candidate for photodetection.[61,176–183]
Theoretical reports have predicted that the mobility of αAsP, α-SbP, and α-SbAs can reach up to ≈104 cm2 V−1 s−1, which is very competitive with values obtained for commercial semiconductors.[65] In addition, according to theoretical progress summarized in Section 2.2, the bandgaps of 2D V-V binary materials cover a wide range from visible to infrared regions (0.4 to ≈3 eV), suggesting their appealing potential in the field of photodetectors. Furthermore, as the phase of materials is changed, their band structures can be tuned accordingly, allowing the materials to exhibit tunable bandgap and effective mass.[74] Therefore, it is possible to design 2D V-V binary material with desired bandgap and carrier mobility, and there is a broad application in next-generation optoelectronics devices.
In 2015, 2D α-AsP materials have been successfully prepared and demonstrated with tunable bandgaps, corresponding to a long-wavelength infrared (LWIR) region. Figure 9a displays the polarization-resolved infrared absorption spectra of α-As0.83P0.17 at different polarization angles, which clearly demonstrate its anisotropic absorption property. Infrared absorption spectra in Figure 9b show the increasing tendency of bandgaps with increasing As concentration in α-AsP. Remarkably, the bandgaps can be efficiently modulated between 0.3 eV (in the case pure α-P) and 0.15 eV (in α-As0.83P0.17), corresponding to the LWIR region. In 2017, Amani et al. carried out a comprehensive investigation on 2D α-AsP photodetectors by changing its thickness and concentration ratio (Figure 9c).[63] The cutoff wavelength is modified by adjusting concentration ratio. The specific detectivity D* is improved by controlling the AsP nanosheets thickness, and the vintage thickness is 25–35 nm. As shown in Figure 9d, in the optimized devices based on α-As0.91P0.09, the peak D* reaches to 2.4 × 1010 cm Hz1/2 W−1 at room temperature.
Miao et al. reported high-performance α-AsP MIR photodetectors, entering the second atmospheric transmission window, as shown in Figure 10a–c.[65] The investigations of the photocurrent generation mechanism in α-AsP flacks are presented in Figure 10a,b. The photocurrent rises linearly as the bias voltage
increases, and a zero-biased photoresponse is observed, suggesting a significant MIR photoresponse. After constructing a vdWH with MoS2, the dark current noise and specific detectivity of α-AsP-based photodetectors were improved obviously. In Figure 10c, the peak D* of junction at room temperature reaches to 9.2 × 109 Jones, which is higher than the value obtained in 3–5 µm range of incident light. Subsequently, h-BN encapsulation was developed to protect α-AsP against degradation and preserve its intrinsic photoconductive effect.[64] The photodetector based on h-BN/α-AsP/h-BN heterostructure
and the corresponding photoresponse performance are shown in Figure 10d–f. At room temperature, the peak responsivities of the photodetector were measured under different incident light. Its photocarrier lifetime for MIR detection revealed a underlying 3 dB cutoff frequency at approximately 19 GHz. The aforementioned excellent performances make α-AsP a potential candidate for MIR optoelectronic applications.
It has been reported that 2D SbAs was predicted to have a direct bandgap, ultrahigh carrier mobility, and giant anisotropic photogalvanic effect, making it a promising alternative material in optoelectronics.[97] Violet SbP has been investigated as an optoelectronic material based on the FET.[132] Violet SbP shows an ≈1.67 eV direct bandgap, encouraging the fabrication of photodetectors under visible light. At room temperature, the FET based on few-layer violet SbP achieves a carrier mobility up to 58.96 cm2 V−1 s−1, a high on–off ratio of ≈103, a peak responsivity of 10 µA W−1, and a resistivity of 1.06 MΩ µm.
Black phosphorene have been reported to be applied in solar cell thanks to its thickness-dependent bandgap and excellent mobility.[184,185] Back to 2016, 2D α-AsP was investigated as an ideal donor material in solar cell, motivated by its 1.54 eV direct bandgap and high electron mobility of 14 380 cm2 V−1 s−1.[62] Following the VBM and CBM levels of α-AsP monolayer, GaN monolayer is chosen as the suitable acceptor material to construct a type-II band alignment. The PCE of the fabricated system can reach up to 22.1%. Besides, the PCE of BiAs/WS2 heterostructure is predicted to approach to 19.6%, indicating that BiAs is also a favorable solar cell donor material.[99]

To achieve high ZT for enhanced thermoelectric performance is a challenge because the transport characteristics in a material are always reciprocally connected. The key to increasing ZT value is to enlarge electronic conductivity σ and reduce thermal conductivity k. Compared with 3D crystals, low-dimensional materials are supposed to be able to get rid of this interconnection escape. Different engineering approaches are implemented to improve the ZT value of various materials including V-V binary crystals. First-principles simulations have indicated that the composition of bulk Bi1−xSbx has no effect on the ZT value.[186] Te doping can enhance the ZT value of bulk Bi1−xSbx by one order of magnitude.[187] Dimensionality engineering can also improve the ZT value. Linseis et al. experimentally measured thermoelectric properties of Bi87Sb13 nanofilms with general thicknesses. The measured results show that its electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and absolute Seebeck coefficient all decreased with the decrease of film thickness, bringing about a largest ZT (0.28) in the thickness of 282 nm.[188] The first-principles calculations with Boltzmann transport indicate that 2D V-V materials show better thermoelectric properties than the corresponding monoelemental materials.[73,81,189] For instance, F-BiP possesses a lower thermal conductivity than black phosphorene. Interestingly, the Rashba SOC effect in β-BiSb mono layer remarkably improves its thermoelectric properties, that the ZT value is enhanced by 78% at room temperature.[190] The strengthened thermoelectric performance benefits from 1D density of states, longer carrier lifetime, and internal electric field of BiSb monolayer. In addition to thermoelectric devices, 2D V-V binary crystals also show potential in catalysis and rechargeable batteries. The band alignments of β-PN, β-Pas, and β-PSb monolayers are suitable for photocatalytic water splitting.[88,124] Interestingly, applying 10% tensile strain on PN monolayer leads to more suitable bandgap and improved absorption from ultraviolet to visible light regions, showing better performance in catalyzing water splitting. In addition, AIMD simulation has showed that PN monolayer keeps stable in aqueous solution, indicating the reliability of PN monolayer in splitting water. Furthermore, nanoporous BiSb presents better electrochemical performance for Na storage than Bi or Sb.[155] Nanoporous Bi2Sb6 exhibits an excellent capacity (562.1 mAh g−1 at 200 mA g−1) and long cycling performance (10 000 cycles) at 1 A g−1 current density. As well as nanoporous structures, 2D configurations with low dimensionality are expected to mitigate the volume expansion and accelerate the transportation of Li or Na ions, indicating 2D BiSb the great potential as the anodes of high-performance ion batteries.[191] Biomedicine is an interdisciplinary field, covering bioimaging, biosensing, phototherapy, tissue engineering, targeted delivery, cancer theranostics, and other fields.[192–194] 2D materials have drawn great interest in biomedical field owing to their enormous surface area and unusual photophysical, photochemical, and photothermal properties. In particular, black phosphorene is expected to be applicable to biomedical fields owing to its good optoelectronic properties, low cytotoxicity, high photothermal conversion efficient, excellent biocompatibility, and biodegradability.[9] Several researches have shown

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
Motivated by the interesting properties and experimental successes of 2D group-VA materials, 2D V-V binary materials have received great attention and become an important member of 2D VA material family. This review first overviews the current research in 2D V-V binary materials from diverse aspects, containing crystal structures, electronic properties, modification approaches, synthetic techniques, and various potential applications (Figure 11). Similar to group-VA materials, 2D V-V binary materials possess unique rich allotropes in layered structure, whose significantly stable phases include puckered α phase and buckled β phase. The two stable phases of 2D V-V binary materials display semiconducting feature, with suitable bandgap from 0.4 to ≈3 eV, and high carrier mobility up to 104 cm2 V−1 s−1. Notably, to further optimize the electronic
properties for better device performance, various modulation methods can be utilized, such as composition control, defect, hole doping, strain field, and heterostructure.
It should be emphasized that the synthesis of 2D V-V binary materials is still in its infancy, reflected in that only four of

them (AsP, SbP, SbAs, and BiSb) have been prepared and the successful production of monolayer thickness has not been realized. Fortunately, advanced characterization techniques for the moment are able to support the clear visualization of structural details down to the atomic level and the accurate measurement of composition. The current challenge is the absence of large area and controllable preparation of atomically thin 2D layers, which is expected to be resolved by developing CVD preparation of 2D V-V binary materials. High yield, high quality, and large-scale preparation of 2D V-V binary materials can significantly accelerate the development of more powerful functional nanodevices. In addition, the unique photoelectronic properties of 2D V-V binary materials also supply the opportunities for extensive practical applications of light modulators, MIR devices, integrated photonics, and photothermal therapy. Overall, considering the current stage of 2D V-V binary materials, the challenges and opportunities in the near future are to explore new interesting phenomena, to realize the large-quantity preparation of high-quality 2D nanosheets, and to hunt for novel applications.
